column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Reduce Acid in Tomato Dishes
#Text=Tomatoes can add wonderful flavor and nutrition to your favorite recipes .
#Text=Tomatoes are very acidic , so they can cause serious problems for those with ulcers or other acid related digestive issues .
#Text=You can reduce the acidity of tomatoes by adding some baking soda after you cook them .
#Text=You can also remove the seeds , reduce the time you cook tomatoes , or add them to a dish raw .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Using Baking Soda
#Text=Cut the tomatoes into pieces .
#Text=Most dishes will require you to cut up the tomatoes anyway .
#Text=You can choose how large or small you want the chunks to be depending on what you are making .
#Text=Note that smaller pieces will heat through more quickly .
#Text=Simmer the tomato chunks at medium heat for about 10 minutes .
#Text=If you are going to add the tomatoes into another hot dish , you may not need to cook them for as long .
#Text=If you cut bigger chunks , you may need to cook them a little longer .
#Text=Be sure to watch the tomatoes carefully so that you can remove them from heat if they start to burn or become too crispy .
#Text=Remove the pan from the burner and stir in 1/4 tsp of baking soda .
#Text=This amount works well for six medium tomatoes , so for more or less tomatoes you can adjust the amount of baking soda .
#Text=Stir the baking soda so that all the pieces of tomato get a slight coating .
#Text=The baking soda will fizz as it reacts with the acid of the tomatoes .
#Text=Add the rest of your ingredients and finish cooking the dish .
#Text=Once the fizzing has stopped , which may take a minute or so , finish cooking the dish .
#Text=The baking soda will reduce the overall acid content of the dish and does not usually alter the taste of the dish .
#Text=Deseeding and Shortening Cook Times
#Text=Remove the seeds from the tomato .
#Text=Carefully slice the tomato in half around what would be the equator line so that one half has the stem and one half has the bottom .
#Text=Then use a ¼ teaspoon , or another small spoon , and scoop the tomato seeds out and discard them .
#Text=Do n’t scrape too deeply into the flesh of the tomato .
#Text=The seeds carry much of the acid content of the tomato plant , so removing them altogether is a great way to reduce the acidity .
#Text=Some dishes are enhanced by cooking the seeds along with the flesh of the tomato , so take this into account before you remove the seeds .
#Text=Reduce the cooking time of tomatoes .
#Text=Tomatoes become more acidic as they cook longer , so reducing the cook time to the least amount possible can help keep the acid level lower .
#Text=Sauces and other dishes that require long simmering may make this difficult , but it is recommended that you do n’t cook tomatoes for longer than 1 ½ hours .
#Text=You may have to get used to using tomatoes that are less cooked , but if you deal with problems stemming from acidic foods it may be worth the effort .
#Text=Add tomatoes last .
#Text=If you dish includes tomatoes , but tomatoes are not the main ingredient , add them after everything else has cooked for the majority of the necessary time .
#Text=Doing this is another way of reducing the cook time , while still cooking them briefly .
#Text=If a dish calls for you to simmer the ingredients for one hour , put the tomatoes in for the last 10 minutes .
#Text=They ’ll have time to warm up and soak into the dish a little bit , but not become overly acidic .
#Text=Use raw tomatoes in the dish .
#Text=In the same way that reducing the cooking time can reduce the acid content , foregoing cooking the tomatoes altogether will reduce the acidity .
#Text=Raw tomatoes are far less acidic than cooked tomatoes .
#Text=If you can include the tomatoes in the dish raw without significantly affecting the dish , this will make them less acidic .
#Text=If you are putting the tomatoes into a hot dish , the other ingredients will most likely heat the tomatoes up enough to even out the temperature of the dish .
#Text=Choosing Tomatoes to Use
#Text=Look for the ripest tomatoes .
#Text=Tomatoes lose some of their acidity as they ripen , so avoid tomatoes that appear to be less that fully ripe .
#Text=Two good ways to check the ripeness of a tomato is to feel the weight and gently squeeze the tomato .
#Text=Choose heavier tomatoes and softer tomatoes .
#Text=Heavier means more juice , which means more ripe .
#Text=Tomatoes that are soft but not mushy are more ripe than hard tomatoes .
#Text=You can also learn the smell of a ripe tomato versus the smell of an unripe tomato .
#Text=Cook with fresh tomatoes .
#Text=The process of canning tomatoes ends up increasing the acidity , so you can reduce acid in your dishes by only cooking with fresh tomatoes .
#Text=You ’ll have to buy fresh tomatoes more frequently than canned ones as they will not last as long .
#Text=Choose non-red tomatoes .
#Text=Tomatoes come in red , green , yellow , orange , and combinations of these , and in most cases non-red varieties of tomatoes are said to be lower in acidity .
#Text=The next time you make your favorite tomato dish , try out some non-red tomatoes and see if you notice a difference in the acidity .
#Text=This is not a hard and fast rule as there are red varieties that are low-acid and non-red varieties that are high-acid .
#Text=Some varieties to keep an eye out for are Yellow pear , a tomato similar to cherry varieties , Georgia Streak , a yellow heirloom variety , and Big Rainbow , a golden-red tomato .
#Text=Quick Summary
